tit.cmt: As we are not talking about one specific building, I think the plural is needed here.

sen.j: 西洋館（せいようかん）とは、幕末、明治時代以降に日本で建設された西洋の建築様式を用いた建物のこと。
sen.e: 西洋館 (seiyo-kan building) indicates the western-style buildings that were built in Japan towards the end of the bakufu era, in the Meiji period and later.
西洋館 (seiyo-kan building) indicates the western-style buildings that were built in Japan towards the end of the bakufu era, in the Meiji period and later.
The Japanese term "Seiyo-kan" is used to describe western-style buildings that were built in Japan from the end of the Edo period and the Meiji period onwards.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。クォーテーションマークを修正

sen.j: 主として住宅を指す。
sen.e: Mainly used for residences.
Mainly used for residences.
These buildings were mainly used as residences.
sen.cmt: In some cases a translation like this may work (when you have bullet points, for example), but as this is part of a paragraph, this is simply a sentence fragment. To make this paragraph work in English, a subject is needed.

sen.j: 洋館、洋風建築とも。
sen.e: Also called 洋館 (yo-kan building) or 洋風建築 (yofu-kenchiku building).
Also called 洋館 (yo-kan building) or 洋風建築 (yofu-kenchiku building).
sen.cmt: I don't understand why kanji has to be used in these sentences.
sen.e: They were also called yo-kan buildings or yofu-kenchiku buildings.
sen.cmt: In some cases a translation like this may work (when you have bullet points, for example), but as this is part of a paragraph, this is simply a sentence fragment. To make this paragraph work in English, a subject is needed.

sen.j: 神戸では明治期のものを異人館、大正～昭和戦前にかけてのものを洋館と呼んで区別している。
sen.e: In Kobe, the seiyo-kan buidings built in the Meiji period are called ijin-kan buildings (former residences of early foreign settlers) and the seiyo-kan buildings built in the period from Taisho to the end of Second World War in Showa is called yo-kan buildings.

In Kobe, the seiyo-kan buidings built in the Meiji period are called ijin-kan buildings (former residences of early foreign settlers); and, the seiyo-kan buildings built in the period from Taisho to the end of Second World War in Showa is called yo-kan buildings.

In Kobe, seiyo-kan buildings that were built in the Meiji period are called ijin-kan buildings (former residences of early foreign settlers), while those that were built during the Taisho period and during the Showa period prior to the start of the Second World War are called yo-kan buildings.
sen.cmt: This still seemed to require some editing, particularly the incorrect subject verb agreement at the end of the sentence.

sen.j: 居留地建築など
sen.e: Buildings in foreign settlements, etc.
Buildings in foreign settlements etc.
Buildings in foreign settlements etc.

sen.j: 長崎、横浜、神戸など外国人の外国人居留地には、外国人の住宅（異人館）、事務所、学校、教会などが建設され、従来の日本とは異質な街並みが生まれた。
sen.e: In the foreign settlements in Nagasaki, Yokohama and Kobe, houses (ijin-kan buildings), office buidings, schools and churches were built, generating street landscapes different from the traditional Japanese one.

In the foreign settlements in Nagasaki, Yokohama and Kobe, houses (ijin-kan buildings), office buidings, schools and churches were built, generating street landscapes different from traditional Japan.

In the foreign settlements at Nagasaki, Yokohama and Kobe, private houses (ijin-kan buildings), office buildings, schools and churches for foreigners were built, generating street landscapes different from traditional Japan.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: これらは外国から技師・技術者が来て建設したものもあるが、日本人の職人にデザインなどを指示して建設したものもある。
sen.e: Some of them were built by foreign engineers who came to Japan, but there are others that were built by Japanese craftmen based on designs instructed by foreign engineers.
Some of them were built by foreign engineers who came to Japan, but there are others that were built by Japanese craftmen based on designs taught by foreign engineers.
Some of them were built by foreign engineers who came to Japan, but there are others that were built by Japanese craftsmen based on designs taught by foreign engineers.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 擬洋風建築
sen.e: Qusai-yofu-kenchiku (Qusai-western-style buildings)
??-yofu-kenchiku (Quasi-western-style buildings)
Quasi-western-style buildings
sen.cmt: I can see why giving a romaji rendering of the Japanese is necessary above, but I think the English alone is sufficient as a heading in this case. At any rate, putting "quasi" before a Japanese term is likely to confuse the reader.

sen.j: 居留地建築に刺激を受けた日本の大工棟梁は、見よう見まねで西洋のデザインを採り入れた事務所、ホテル、学校などを建設した。
sen.e: Japanese master carpenters stimulated by buildings in foreign settlements mimicked the designs of these buildings and built office buildings, hotels and schools where western-style designs were introduced.

Japanese master carpenters stimulated by buildings in foreign settlements mimicked the designs of these buildings and built office buildings, hotels and schools where western-style designs were introduced.
Japanese master carpenters were stimulated by buildings in foreign settlements and they built office buildings, hotels and schools mimicking the western-style design.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 伝統的な職人の技術をベースに洋風要素を採り入れたこれらのものを擬洋風建築と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The western-style buildings that Japanese craftmen built based on their traditional techniques are called qusai-yofu-kenchiku (Qusai-western-style buildings).
The western-style buildings that Japanese craftmen built based on their traditional techniques are called ??-yofu-kenchiku (Quasi-western-style buildings).
The western-style buildings that Japanese craftsmen built based on their traditional techniques are called Gi-yofu-kenchiku (literally, "quasi-western-style buildings").
sen.cmt: As the Japanese term is being defined here, I don't think we have much choice but to include the romaji rendering of the entire term and then provide a translation in parentheses.

sen.j: 外国人技師の建築
sen.e: Buildings built by foreign engineers
Buildings built by foreign engineers
Buildings built by foreign engineers

sen.j: お雇い外国人の指導により建設された工場、都市建築などがある。
sen.e: Factories and urban buildings were builts by employed foreigners.
Factories and urban buildings were built by employed foreigners.
Factories and urban buildings were built by employed foreigners.

sen.j: 銀座煉瓦街、富岡製糸場などはその代表的なものである。
sen.e: Ginza Renga-gai (bricktown or brick street) and Tomioka Seishi-jo (Tomioka Silk Mill) are typical such examples.
Ginza Renga-gai (bricktown or brick street) and Tomioka Seishi-jo (Tomioka Silk Mill) are typical examples.
Ginza Renga-gai (bricktown or brick street) and Tomioka Seishi-jo (Tomioka Silk Mill) are typical examples.

sen.j: 日本人建築家の作品
sen.e: Products by Japanese building archtects
Products by Japanese building archtects
Products by Japanese building architects
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: お雇い外国人ジョサイア・コンドルが日本人にはじめて本格的・体系的な建築教育を行い、辰野金吾らの日本人建築家を育成した。
sen.e: Josiah CONDOR, an employed foreigner, conducted full-fledged and systematic building education to Japanese, bringing up Japanese building archtects, such as Kingo TATSUNO.
Josiah CONDOR, an employed foreigner, provided full-fledged and systematic building education to Japanese; training Japanese building architects, such as Kingo TATSUNO.
Josiah CONDOR, an employed foreigner, was the first to provide serious and systematic architecture education to Japan and trained Japanese building architects, such as Kingo TATSUNO.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 正規の教育を受けた建築家が中心になり、ヨーロッパの建築様式を採りいれ、官庁や事務所、住宅などの西洋館が建設されるようになった（東京駅など規模の大きなものは西洋館とは呼びにくいが、建築ガイド本などで総称して含める場合もある）。
sen.e: Centered on the building architects who received formal education, seiyo-kan buildings for goverment/agency offices and houses were built employing building styles in Europe (it seems difficult to include large-scale buildings, such as Tokyo Station, into the category of seiyo-kan buildings, but they are sometimes included in the category, for example, in building guide books, using the term more gnerally).

Centered on the building architects who received formal education, seiyo-kan buildings for goverment/agency offices and houses were built employing European building styles (it seems difficult to include large-scale buildings, such as Tokyo Station, into the category of seiyo-kan buildings, but they are sometimes included in the category, for example, in building guide books, using the term more gnerally).

Architects who received formal education took the lead in building seiyo-kan buildings for government/agency offices and houses employing European building styles (strictly speaking, large-scale buildings, such as Tokyo Station, are not seiyo-kan buildings, but architecture guide books sometimes use the term more broadly).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 上記のような西洋館に刺激されて、次第に各地域でも地元の職人による西洋館が建てられるようになった。
sen.e: Stimulated by the seiyo-kan buidings described above, seiyo-kan buidings were beginning to be gradually built in various areas by local craftmen.
Stimulated by the seiyo-kan buidings described above, seiyo-kan buidings were beginning to be gradually built in various areas by local craftsmen.
Stimulated by the seiyo-kan buildings described above, seiyo-kan buildings began to be built by local craftsmen in various regions.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。ピリオドを削除

sen.j: 写真館や病院・医院、学校などでは西洋風のデザインが好まれた。
sen.e: Western-style designs were favored by photo studios, hospitals, clinics and schools.
Western-style designs were favored by photo studios, hospitals, clinics and schools.
Western-style designs were favored by photo studios, hospitals, clinics and schools.

sen.j: 明治以降の社会でも、一般的な住居は日本の住宅であった。
sen.e: Even in and after the Meiji period, houses of the general public continued being Japanese-style ones.
Even in and after the Meiji period, houses of the general public continued being Japanese-style ones.
Even after the Meiji period, private houses continued to be in the Japanese-style.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 一部の政治家や実業家などで、進んで西洋風の生活スタイルを採り入れるために西洋館を建設したものもいる。
sen.e: Some politicians and businessmen built seiyo-kan buildings to employ western life styles willingly.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Some politicians and businessmen built seiyo-kan buildings to incorporate Western lifestyles willingly.
Some politicians and businessmen built seiyo-kan buildings to willingly incorporate Western lifestyle.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 天井が高く、開放性が低い西洋館の造りは四季の気温の変化が大きく多雨多湿の日本の風土とは必ずしも適合しない面があった。
sen.e: However, being provided with high ceilings and smaller wall spaces that can be opened outside, the structure of seiyo-kan buildings was not completely fitted to the Japanese climate in which air temperatures in each of the four seasons are different considerably, it rains frequently and the humidity is high.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, being provided with high ceilings and smaller wall spaces that can be opened outside, the structure of seiyo-kan buildings was not completely fitted to the Japanese climate in which temperatures fluctuate considerably through each of the four seasons, it rains frequently and the humidity is high.

However, the structure of seiyo-kan buildings with its high ceilings and closed spaces was not suitable for the Japanese climate in which temperatures fluctuate considerably throughout the four seasons with frequent rains and high humidity.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。スペースを挿入

sen.j: 伝統的な和風住宅が圧倒的な時代に造られた西洋館には、エキゾチックなイメージと怪しげな雰囲気が醸し出され、しばしば探偵小説などの舞台になった。
sen.e: Seiyo-kan buildings built in the era when traditional Japanese houses were dominant generated an exotic image and seedy atmosphere, and were frequently used in mystery stories and others.
Seiyo-kan buildings built in the era when traditional Japanese houses were dominant generated an exotic image and atmosphere of mystique, and were frequently used in mystery stories and others.
In an age when traditional Japanese houses were the majority, seiyo-kan buildings had an exotic image and mysterious atmosphere, and were frequently used as a setting for detective stories.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: （黒死館殺人事件など）
sen.e: (Kokusikan-satsujin-jiken (litellerly, a murder case in a black-death residence), etc.)
(Stories such as Kokusikan-satsujin-jiken [literally, a murder case in a black-death residence] etc.)
(Stories such as Kokushikan-satsujin-jiken (literally, murder at the black-death house))
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 昭和の戦前期から戦後にかけて、生活スタイルは急激に変化し、住宅の形式も大きく変わった。
sen.e: The life styles and housing styles in the post-war era have become largely different from those in the pre-war era.
The lifestyles and housing styles in the post-war era have become largely different from those in the pre-war era.
Lifestyle and housing style changed drastically from the pre-war era to the post-war era of the Showa period.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 過去の様式を否定するモダニズム建築の影響も受けながら、日本の風土に合わせて工夫された住宅が、伝統的な和風住宅よりも優勢になってきた。
sen.e: Although housing has been affected by modernism-based buildings that denys past building styles, the houses that have introduced designs more fitted to the Japanese climate have become to be more favored than traditional Japanese style houses.

Although housing has been influenced by modernist-based buildings that deny past building styles, these houses have introduced designs more fitted to the Japanese climate and have come to be more favored than traditional Japanese style houses.

Although housing has been influenced by modernist architecture that deny past building styles, houses that have been designed to suit the Japanese climate have come to be more favored than traditional Japanese style houses.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 欧米化が普及した今日、床の間や和室のない住宅であっても、西洋館と呼ぶことはない。
sen.e: Things in Japan have been increasingly more westernized, and houses without tokonoma (alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed) nor a Japanese style room are not called seiyo-kan buildings, just because they lack of such typical Japanes styles.

Things in Japan have been increasingly more Westernized, and houses lacking tokonoma (the alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed) and a Japanese style room are never called seiyo-kan buildings, because they lack these typically Japanese styles.

Things in Japan have become increasingly Westernized now and houses lacking tokonoma (the alcove in a traditional Japanese room where art or flowers are displayed) and a Japanese-style tatami room would not be called seiyo-kan buildings anymore.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 和風住宅が一般的であった時代にあえて洋風の住まいを建てたからこそ、西洋館という呼び方をしたのだと考えられる。
sen.e: It is considered that the name of seiyo-kan was used because western style buildings were built while Japanese style buildings existed dominantly.
It is thought that the term seiyo-kan was used because these Western-style buildings were built at a time when Japanese-style buildings dominated.
